top_comment.author: Conspiracy News Network

comments.text:
+Shawna Rose Nixon Whether, in fact, all governments are coporations or 
not, and I continue to believe they are, they are run as such and, thus, 
should be approached as though they are. Regulation is meaningless except 
perhaps as a way to slowly strangle the government out of existance. A very 
cruel method I'd say. Better to just cut its throat and be done.
Those metaphors suddenly became rather bloody. :P
comments.author: Lucus Rose

comments.text:
+Shawna Rose Nixon Order imposed is undue order.  The necessary order 
already exists. Yes, a system will arise to replace a system overthrown. If 
we have learned our lessons a better one. But, as I have said, systems have 
built-in self preservation mechanisms and will almost always last longer 
than they should. Thus, overthrow is the natural and best way to deal with 
this.  Replacement is a natural, organic process. It should not be hurried 
or manipulated. There is a symbiotic relationship between a system and its 
members and a system that comes into being organicly will, by default, meet 
their needs.
comments.author: Lucus Rose

comments.text:
+Lucus Rose
I agree that the balance of power between the Federal Government and the 
States lies far too heavily on the Federal Government.  More local control 
would help empower more people.  However, I think that power imbalance can 
still be dealt with from within.

As for your argument about Constitutions, it does not follow that all 
governments are corporations.  "All corporations have constitutions, and 
all governments have constitutions, therefore all governments are 
corporations" makes as little logical sense as "All girls have mothers, and 
all boys have mothers, therefore all boys are girls."  It may be true 
(though I believe it is not), but it doesn't follow logically from your 
argument.

I agree that there is too much corporate control of government, however.  
The solution to that is more regulation and oversight, not less.
comments.author: Shawna Rose Nixon

comments.text:
+Lucus Rose
I agree, Chaos should be sought... up to a point.  Chaos can easily become 
overwhelming and harmful if it is not tempered by Order, however.  The 
needs of others are a natural, pre-existing thing, but how those needs are 
expressed is a dynamic pattern, which imposes both Order and Chaos upon 
us.  The Order imposed by government is a result of those around us, over 
generations, creating a system to meet their needs.  We, as citizens of 
that government, have some little power to affect that system, but there 
are others, some of them powerful, who also affect the system.

The solution is not necessarily to overthrow the system, because a system 
WILL arise to replace it.  People need Order as well as Chaos to function, 
and they will seek it out.  A better solution is to work with one's allies 
to change the system to meet one's needs, if possible.  If you want to 
demolish the current system, what would you replace it with?  How would you 
ensure that the new system met the needs of you and those around you?

A uncontrolled mass of cells without structure is cancer, pure and simple.  
We need both Chaos and Order to survive.
comments.author: Shawna Rose Nixon

comments.text:
+Shawna Rose Nixon If freedom is chaos, then chaos is what should be 
sought. The order you mentioned, that constrains your freedom is a natural 
pre-existant thing. It is the only constraint that is necessary and should 
be allowed. Anything beyond that is the product of fallible individuals 
 attempting to impose their will on others to gain their percieved needs 
whether of safety or pleasure. This is unacceptable aggression against 
other individuals.
The Constitution, from the beginning, was designed to take freedom, 
primarily from the states which until that time could be considered 
seperate countries and were busy quarreling with each other. When you take 
freedom from the states, you also take freedom from the individuals within 
those states. Todays states are little more than puppets of the federal 
government. The majority of their funding for the things they do comes from 
the federal government. Perhaps, the fight should be in each state to 
get FEDERAL money out of state government.
I would finish with these thoughts. A Constitution is the controling 
document of a corporation. Its foundation, so to speak. Thus all 
governments are Corporations. Special types of coporations, but coporations 
nonetheless. They are always interested in the bottom line. Are they not 
always crying about the same financial terms that every corporation deals 
with every day? Does not the government treat these coporations as if they 
were wholely owned subsidaries of itself, taking a part of the profits 
(taxes)? Another reason why personal taxes could be considered a form of 
double dipping. So in fighting whatever coporate control of the government 
there is, are you not limiting the ability of those "employees" to fair 
representation. And yes, what they want is more than their fair 
representation. Should not the real enemy be the Corporation over all 
others, the federal government?
comments.author: Lucus Rose

comments.text:
+Lucus Rose

Freedom is Chaos, pure and simple.  It's usually a beneficial Chaos, but it 
is Chaos, nonetheless.  It's certainly not Order.  Chaos, or Entropy, is 
one of the basic forces of the universe.  Freedom, and other flavors of 
Chaos, can be and almost always are constrained by Order of some kind.  My 
freedom to do what I will is constrained at a basic level by 1) the pattern 
of my abilities  and 2) the pattern of the reactions of others.  Freedom is 
always on a continuum.  I am freer in some areas than others, and always 
will be.

As for the benefits of hierarchy, hierarchical structures are risky, but 
they are also very effective.  WolfPAC has a natural endpoint of getting a 
constitutional convention.   If it starts going beyond that endpoint, I 
will take a close look at what further ends it is after.  If WolfPAC starts 
using questionable means for its ends, then I will absolutely speak up.  
Hierarchical systems require vigilant monitoring by the rank and file, and 
need to maintain enough freedom that the rank and file can act on their 
observations.

On to the Constitution.  You have a good point, the Constitution is ignored 
and misinterpreted more often than I'd like.  However, I think the basic 
structure is still sound.  I'm willing to hear your arguments as to why it 
is not.  The Constitution is imperfect and corruptible, but it still 
protects us to some extent.  Adding more words adds to the protections we 
can call on, even if they don't always work.

Furthermore, simply by engaging in the government, corrupt as it is, simply 
by exercising our small power as citizens, we increase our power to make 
change and oppose those in power.  Part of the reason that power is so 
entrenched at the top is because common citizens have done little to 
exercise our rights.  Use 'em or lose 'em.  I'm not saying that's what 
should happen; I'm saying that's what does happen.  Simply trying, even if 
we fail in the short term, makes a big difference.  If nothing else, it can 
increase our odds for later success.
comments.author: Shawna Rose Nixon

comments.text:
+Shawna Rose Nixon I do not believe that chaos exists except in the minds 
of the weak and frightened. A fair amount of freedom is no freedom at all. 
Freedom cannot be  be cut into fractions, it either is or isn't. I do not 
trust hierarchical structures to successfully perform a task not only due 
to the ease in which they can be corrupted by only a few near the top, but 
also because hierarchical structures, by nature, have an inclination 
towards self-preservation that often results in self-sabotage of the 
mission or redefining of the mission to prolong its life. It most often 
requires an outside force to bring its existance to an end.
That said, rather than a long explanation of how anti-freedom the 
Constitution is, I'll simply ask a question. What good will adding more 
words do, when the document is either ignored or reinterperted by those in 
power to sustain their actions?
comments.author: Lucus Rose

comments.text:
+Lucus Rose
If we have systems without freedom, we are enslaved by Order.  If we have 
freedom without systems, we are victims to Chaos.  We need Order and Chaos, 
systems with freedom, working in a healthy way, in order to function.  Thus 
far, WolfPAC seems to be working on a vital problem, with relatively little 
corruption.  The structure is hierarchical, but members still have a fair 
amount of freedom.  Like +cmatrix4761 , I will be alert for signs of 
corruption, because corruption can happen to anyone and anything.  WolfPAC 
seems to be gaining power, and is capable of harming its adversaries, which 
is a risk, but seems to be necessary in meeting its aims for a 
constitutional amendment to get money out of politics.  In short, I fully 
support WolfPAC for now, as its ends are good and its means are fairly 
ethical.
comments.author: Shawna Rose Nixon

comments.text:
+cmatrix4761 Good points made.  My first thought at start of 
reading....I've heard/been told, "there is no such thing as rational man."
comments.author: Johnetta Hooper

comments.text:
+Lucus Rose To me, there cannot be an objective morality. Morality is 
defined by the individual. If it was proven tomorrow that it's "objectively 
moral" to rape people then I'd still think it was immoral because morality 
is personal. I don't even know what an objective morality would entail and 
I think it's a completely nonsensical notion. If it's defined by a deity 
then it's just the deity's subjective morality. If it's some intrinsic 
state of the universe then what makes it moral or anything to do with 
morality? Even if I was a theist (which as you guessed, I am not, but at 
one point I would have classed myself that way) then I still couldn't get 
behind the notion that anything is objectively moral.

And even if it existed outside of societal constructs, we have no way of 
knowing for sure what it is and we definitely don't societally adhere to it 
so it doesn't really matter when discussing system of government. When you 
can prove that it exists and what it says, then we can start having a 
conversation on whether we should adhere to it and whether it's even moral 
at all.
comments.author: Person Oisels

comments.text:
+Person Oisels
Well, facing the consequences is a place where I do agree with you on 
corruption interfering with consequences.

Your answer on morality leads me to think you are an atheist. I am a 
theist, though not a christian, muslim or jewish one. It is doubtful we 
could find agreement here as I belive morality exists outside of a societal 
construct. Rather the societal construct filters the expression of morality.

I have enjoyed this discussion and hope you have as well.
comments.author: Lucus Rose

comments.text:
+Lucus Rose Yes, but your own point before was that that doesn't remove 
freedom. This is what you said, it doesn't remove anyone's freedom, they 
just have to face consequences for exercising their freedom.

I don't entirely understand what you mean by "the source of morality". 
Morality is a thing made up by people. Everyone's morality is likely 
slightly different in some way. Where the majority find common ground, they 
make laws (so long as such a law would be compatible with the rest of their 
morality - excepting in cases where people's own morality is inconsistent 
with itself, usually when someone is an idiot who doesn't think about it).
comments.author: Person Oisels

comments.text:
+Person Oisels I would modify my statement to all systems attempt to remove 
freedom. This is done by using simple force, engendering fear and 
engendering loyalty. Again, this is slightly off topic.

Your statement about corruption is interesting. There are very few people 
who would agree with your statement. It borders on the end justifying the 
means. After all, a totally corrupt system that simultaneously provides for 
all the people without any major damage to those people could be viewed as 
acceptable even though unnecessary.

At this point I would need to know your views on the source of morality 
before I comment further.
comments.author: Lucus Rose

comments.text:
+Lucus Rose Well then you've just defeated your own statement because very 
few systems except things like Nazism takes away anyone's freedom.

Corruption isn't "hurting everyone", it's dishonest and fraudulent conduct 
by officials, typically involving bribery. It doesn't matter what they're 
actually doing, so long as they're doing that. It's not required that they 
be hurting the interests of the people under them. Although that's usually 
the end result, because you don't have to be a fraud, taking bribes if 
you're acting in the best interests of the people.
comments.author: Person Oisels

comments.text:
+Person Oisels Everyone has the "freedom" to murder. There is simply a 
penalty to pay for the act. But that would take this conversation in a 
different direction than we started with.
"even if the system right now was actually working for the best interests 
of the people then it would still be corrupt." Could you expand on this 
statement? I interests me.
comments.author: Lucus Rose

comments.text:
+Lucus Rose the conclusion does not follow from the premise even if we 
accept it as true.

Just because something is "inimical to freedom" because it "constrains 
actions" doesn't make it not good for the people or not what it was meant 
to be. Furthermore, the non-constraint of action does not offer true 
freedom either. give one person the freedom to murder and someone else's 
freedoms are taken away.

If what they're working for is how the system was designed to be and 
they're honest about what they're doing then it is by definition not 
corruption. It doesn't even matter what is "best", even if the system right 
now was actually working for the best interests of the people then it would 
still be corrupt. Although I think most people would agree that it is not 
working in their best interests.
comments.author: Person Oisels

comments.text:
+Person Oisels
I wasn't as exact as I should have been. They are buying it for the 
ideology they espouse, which they honestly believe is best for the american 
people and represents what the system was meant to be. They are wrong. All 
systems constrain action and are therefore inimical to freedom.
comments.author: Lucus Rose

comments.text:
+Lucus Rose No, you're wrong. You claim that their goal is to "buy it for 
themselves" but this statement goes against what they're actually doing and 
you're going to need to show some evidence. They're "buying" it for the 
american people, to stop individuals from buying it, which is how the 
system is DESIGNED to be and therefore cannot be called corrupt. Of course, 
if they were just buying it for themselves then that would be corruption, 
but there's no evidence that's what they're doing. Just because the system 
is corrupt does not mean that operating within the system to make it less 
corrupt will inherently make you corrupt.
comments.author: Person Oisels

comments.text:
+Person Oisels
This is the disconnect I am trying to point out. "rather the system is 
corrupt, and pacs are part of that system. Wolfpac is trying to change the 
system through the system." As a PAC, including Wolfpac, is part of the 
system and the system is corrupt, then its parts, including Wolpac, either 
is or will become corrupt.
Next, "they're trying to use democracy to achieve it. they're not doing it 
for money just with money." To simplify that statement, the problem is 
money in politics, so they want to fix it by pumping more money into 
politics. They want to buy the government from its current owners for 
themselves because they believe they know better than the current owners. 
They'll deny that, of course, and that's because they are blind to that 
fact. Its nothing more than a fight between ideologies. Politics as it has 
been through the ages.
comments.author: Lucus Rose

comments.text:
That assumes that anyone is claiming that ALL other pacs are corrupt. 
That's not what anyone is saying, rather the system is corrupt, and pacs 
are part of that system. Wolfpac is trying to change the system through the 
system. Look at the goals, look at the ideals and the beliefs behind them

taken negatively, I just try to be objective when pointing out common 
errors.

results in you being able to type such a backwards comment?  *HINT*  It 
wasn't blacks or mexicans.  Whites are inferior at upper education?  #ROFL 
who do you think writes the tests?  =)

captions.text: Last night
it was a democratic bloodbath
a lot of democratic legislators across the country
almost all of them in close races lost
but not everyone who was fighting for the right causes in the country lost
In fact some of the people who were fighting the hardest won
who were they?
well they were people supported by WOLF PAC
WOLF PAC is the group that has been formed to get money out of politics
We want to pass a constitutional amendment
Now people are worried, Oh my god the republicans control, the senate and the house
well on the national level you should be worried because...those guys.
make a living out of money in politics
people like Mitch McConnell
who actually loves citizens united and defended it
but theres a lot of republicans across the country who are at the state level who dont like....money
coming into their states whether its Bloomberg money Soros money or even Koch and Rove money
at the state level it turns out you can get an ammendment without washington at all
and thats exactly what WOLF PAC intends to do
now in some states we've had some good fortune
well of course that fortune was earned through alot of hard-work
including the states of Vermont and California that have already passed a resolution calling
for the convention to get us that amendment...so that we can end this corruption
that 95% of americans know exist...are sick of
So in Vermont we had someone help us..just a citizen!
HIs name was Dr. Steve Berry
and..he was a minister
and...uh
and he was a concerned citizen
who cared about what was happening in Vermont
we faced a obstacle there
There was some state legislators who were um...skeptical about a convention
skeptical about this resolution
and we were lucky and again
luck earned through hardwork
one of our workers in New Jersey Walker Greene..one of our leaders there
along with many other people who were doing a WOLF PAC attack in order to get this passed in Vermont
happened to reach Steve Berry just calling citizens in Vermont
and talked him into supporting this resolution
Steve Berry then did a herculean task of talking his legislators
Including Senator Sears into changing their minds and supporting our resolution
and thats why we won in Vermont!
now why do I tell you that story?
because you know what we decided
hey why not support the good guys?
we believe in carrot and sticks
and I'm gonna tell you about the sticks in a minute
but in this case wherever this flag is flown we take care of our own
So we asked Steve Berry to run for office
facing long odds you know...a tight race
very very tight as your gonna see in a second
so we decided hey you know what?
If Steve Berry's got our back we got his back!
we went and worked for him
we went to Vermont we had volunteers go to Vermont
at the very local level
and Steve Berry a regular citizen who cared about the issues...is now a state legislator in Vermont!
put one on the board for WOLF PAC!
Then we go to New Hampshire
In New Hampshire we had a great guy named Tim Smith who was a state legislator there
he introduced our resolution
again wherever this flag is flown we protect our own
So Tim Smith is in a tough re-election race
we went...we got volunteers..we got the WOLF PAC to go there
we supported him...Tim Smith re-elected
and now the margins...im gonna show you the margins in a second
but the most interesting case
a guy named Steve Valencourt
that I've been telling you about
he decided he was going to oppose our resolution
and back then...I talked about it when we lost in New Hampshire
honestly because of Steve Valencourt
Here's me explaining it back then
There's a totally out of control Republican representative in New Hampshire
now look there are republicans on our side in many states
enthusiastically supporting this legislation because they understand we gotta get money out of politics
and its corrupted our democracy
but apparently Representative Valencourt in New Hampshire is not one of them
so..he decided just before the vote was gonna go
that he would do a motion to table the resolution
now...when he did that he said
"look there's a bunch of more important matters pending and this issue doesn't rise to that priority"
well defeating Steve Valencourt rose to the level of priority for us when he did that
he wound up affecting the whole republican party and killing the legislation i'll explain that part here
now of course...people like representative Valencourt don't want to fix the government
they love the broken system!
and unfortunately his fellow republicans went along with it
and they tabled the resolution
so it was killed!
and I said at the end of that video many many months ago
hey we may wanna do something about this
watch
the Valencourts are the bad guys of the world
so....when we do good things and when we have progress I wanna celebrate it
and we do on the show
and we have guys impeding our progress
and its imporant they dont impede it anymore
he didn't win his election by much last time
and soon we'll be calling him former Representative Valencourt from New Hampshire
you can go ahead and call him former Representative Valencourt right now
cause we done got him
do you know what we did?
we moved into his district
literally
The executive director for WOLF PAC moved from Maryland not just to New Hampshire but to Valencourts district
because we made a decision
you come for us...no no no we come for you!
what did I say when we formed WOLF PAC!?!?!
I said were done running
they're not coming for us anymore
we're coming for them
we're not playing around
this is real politics
we came to his house
he was a six term incumbent
no more
clean up go home
let me show you how tight these races were
Steve Berry won by just 73 votes
in the cold both in Vermont and New Hampshire
we sent WOLF PAC seal team six
I'm not kidding...from all across the country
we poured into those states
while no one was looking while people are looking while people are worried about corporatist democrat x vs corporatist republican y
we where in there getting the results
that we needed!
Steve Berry said in his speech after the victory
clearly couldn't have done it without us
and we couldnt have done Vermont without him
that's how we get each others back
Tim Smith won by just 99 votes
but all wins happen because we worked really hard together
and finally Vaillancourt six term incumbent
defeated by 89 votes
ohh we worked hard
oh you shoulda have seen those guys
they went door to door
there were a lotta of sticks brought out
it was not an accident that Valiencourt lost
and he most certainly would not have lost
if we didnt have our entire team there
and by the way WOLF PAC members from all across the country
calling in
what we do is we get people inside those districts
to actually change their minds
you know whats called? Democracy!
thats how you're supposed to do it!
I'd like to tell you the last words former Representive Valiencourt heard in his career
WOLF PAC sends it's regards

title: This Is What Happens When Wolf Pac Attacks
